  <script>
    window.seGlobalMethods = window.seGlobalMethods || {};
    seGlobalMethods.observeIntersection = (element, callback) => {
      const thresholdArray = steps => Array(steps + 1)
       .fill(0)
       .map((_, index) => index / steps || 0)

      const handleIntersect = entries => {
        entries.forEach(entry => {
          callback(entry);
        });
      }

      const observer = new IntersectionObserver(handleIntersect, {
        threshold: thresholdArray(20),
      });
      observer.observe(element);
    }
  </script>

function handlePaginationClick(page_index, pagination_container) {

  var comment_count = this["comments"].length;
  var max_num = Math.min((page_index+1) * numCommentsPerPage, comment_count);

  var commentRange = '';
  if ((max_num < comment_count) || (max_num > numCommentsPerPage)) {
    commentRange += "(" + (page_index*numCommentsPerPage + 1) + " - " + max_num + ") of ";
  }

  $('#commentRange-' + this["post_id"]).html(commentRange);
  showComments(this["blog_id"], this["post_id"], this["comments"], page_index*numCommentsPerPage, max_num, this["author_username"]);
  
  if (jumpToTopOfComments) {
    document.getElementById('comments-' + this["post_id"]).scrollIntoView();
  }

  return false;
} // handlePaginationClick

  $('a.comment-display-btn[href="' + thishref + '"]').css("display","");
  $(thishref).addClass('hidden');
});


function showComments(blog_id, post_id, comments, startNum, endNum, author_username)
{
  var commentContent = '';
  var commentAuthor = '';
  var regex = new RegExp("\n", "g"); 

  var urlRegex =/(\b(https?):\/\/(www)?\.amazon[-A-Z0-9+&@#\/%?=~_|!:,.;]*[-A-Z0-9+&@#\/%=~_|])/ig;

  for (var i = startNum;i < endNum;i++) {

    try {

      comments[i]["text"] = comments[i]["content"].replace(urlRegex, function(url) {  
        var amazonUrl = new URL(url);
        if (amazonUrl["search"].length > 0)
          amazonUrl["search"] += "&tag=se-comment-20";
        else
          amazonUrl["search"] += "?tag=se-comment-20";
        return amazonUrl.href;
      });
    }
    catch (e) {}
    
    commentAuthor = comments[i]["author"];
    commentContent += '<a name="' + comments[i]["id"] + '"></a>';
    commentContent += '<div class="comment';

    var isAuthor = false;
    var isStaff = false;
    var staffLabel = "";
    // Try to look up staff slug by comment author
    var staffSlug = (function(){
      for (var i=0,j=_seStaff.length;i<j;i++) {
        if (_seStaff[i].name == commentAuthor) {
          return _seStaff[i].slug;
        }
      }
      return "";
    })();

    // TODO: Fix this (`commentAuthor` is name and `author_username` is username)
    if (commentAuthor == author_username) {
      isAuthor = true;
      // If author is not staff, build a URL with their username
      if (staffSlug === "") {
        staffSlug = "user/profile/" + commentAuthor.trim().replace(" ", "-").toLowerCase();
      }
      commentContent += ' author';
    } else if (staffSlug !== "") {
      commentContent += ' staff';
      isStaff = true;
      staffLabel = '<span class="label staff-user">Staff</span>';
    }
    
    commentContent += '" id="' + comments[i]["id"] + '">';
    
    commentContent += '<footer class="metadata">';
    if (isStaff || isAuthor)
      commentContent += '<a href="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/' + staffSlug + '" class="commenter';
    else
      commentContent += '<span class="commenter"';

    commentContent += '">' + comments[i]["author"];

    if (isStaff || isAuthor)      
      commentContent += '</a>';
    else
      commentContent += '</span>';

    commentContent += staffLabel + '<span>';
    var comment_date = comments[i]["date"];
    var comment_year = parseInt(comment_date.substr(0,4));
    var comment_month = parseInt(comment_date.substr(5,2));
    var comment_day = parseInt(comment_date.substr(8,2));
    var comment_hour = parseInt(comment_date.substr(11,2));
    // Pad with leading zero
    var comment_minute = ("0" + parseInt(comment_date.substr(14,2))).slice(-2);
    var comment_ampm = comment_hour >= 12 ? 'PM' : 'AM';
    comment_hour = comment_hour % 12;
    comment_hour = comment_hour ? comment_hour : 12;
    commentContent +=  comment_hour + ":" + comment_minute + " " + comment_ampm + " on " + comment_month + "/" + comment_day + "/" + comment_year + '</span></footer>';
    //commentContent += '<div class="comment-body"><div class="recipe-comment-checkbox"><input type="checkbox" name="include-comment" class="include-comment" value="' + comments[i]["comment_id"] + '"';
    commentContent += '<div class="comment-body">';
/*
    // check to see if this comment is in the recipeCommentsToInclude array
    if ((jQuery.inArray((comments[i]["comment_id"]), recipeCommentsToInclude)) >= 0) {
      commentContent += 'checked ';
    }
*/
    // commentContent += '</div>';
    if (comments[i]["rating"] && (comments[i]["rating"] > 0))
    {
      var star_full = '<i class="icon icon-nav-star-full"></i>';
      var star_empty = '<i class="icon icon-nav-star-empty"></i>';
      commentContent += '<div class="rating rating-user"><span class="label">recipe rating:</span><span class="info rating-stars">';
      for (var j = 0; j < 5; j++) {
        
        if (j < comments[i]["rating"])
          commentContent += star_full;
        else
          commentContent += star_empty;
      }
      commentContent += '</span></div>';
    }
    commentContent += '<div class="comment-content">' + comments[i]["text"].replace(regex, "<br />") + '</div></div>';
    commentContent += '</div>';   
  }
// #raw  

  $("section#comments-" + post_id).find("#commentSection").html(commentContent);

  // $('#commentSection').html(commentContent);

/* TODO -- move to printer page

    var comment_id = $(this).attr('value');
    $("div.comment#" + comment_id).toggleClass("comment-print");

    if ($(this).is(':checked')) { 
      var arrayIndex = (jQuery.inArray(comment_id, recipeCommentsToInclude));
      if (arrayIndex < 0) {
        recipeCommentsToInclude.push(comment_id);
        comments_list = recipeCommentsToInclude.join();
      }
    }
    else {
      var arrayIndex = (jQuery.inArray(comment_id, recipeCommentsToInclude));
      if (arrayIndex >= 0) {
        recipeCommentsToInclude.splice(arrayIndex,1);
        comments_list = recipeCommentsToInclude.join();
      }
    }
  });
*/
}

function showCommentSection(post_id, comments)
{
  // if (!commentsDisplayed)
  // {
    var comment_container = $("section#comments-" + post_id);
    
    var author_username = comment_container.data("author-username");
    var blog_id = comment_container.data("blog-id");

    if (comments == undefined)
      return;

    // console.log(comment_container, comments);

    if (comments.length > 0)
    {
      comment_count = comments.length + " <span>Comment";
      if (comments.length > 1)
        comment_count += "s";
    } else {
      comment_count = "<span>Post a Comment";
    }
    comment_count += "</span>";

  // #if CommentsOpen == True
  //   commentCountText = commentCount;               
  // #end if

    if (comment_container.find('#commentSection').length) 
    {
      if (comment_container.find('#postCommentCount').length)
      {
        comment_container.find("#postCommentCount").html(commentCountText);
      }
      if (comment_container.find(".entryCommentCount").length > 0) 
      {
        comment_container.find(".entryCommentCount").each(function() {
          $(this).html(comment_count);
        });
      }

      if (comments.length <= numCommentsPerPage) {
        showComments(blog_id, post_id, comments, 0, comments.length, author_username);
      } else {
        jumpToTopOfComments = false;
        $(".pagination-" + post_id).pagination(comments.length, {
          items_per_page:numCommentsPerPage,
          num_edge_entries:1,
          num_display_entries:9,
          next_show_always:false,
          prev_show_always:false,
          link_to:"#comments-" + post_id,
          author_username:author_username,
          blog_id:blog_id,
          comments:comments,
          post_id:post_id,
          callback:handlePaginationClick
        });

        jumpToTopOfComments = true;
      }
      commentsDisplayed = true;

      var display_button = $("a#comments-display-btn-" + post_id);
      if (display_button && comments.length > 0)
      {
        display_button.text("Show " + comments.length + " Comments");
        var comment_bubbles = $("div.content-main[data-id=" + post_id + "] span.comment-number");
        for (var i = 0; i < comment_bubbles.length; ++i) 
        {
          $(comment_bubbles[i]).text(comments.length);
        }
      }
    } 

  /*} else {
    clearInterval(intervalID);
  }*/
} // showCommentSection

</script>

  <script>
    var searchOverlayFormEl = document.getElementById('SearchForm');
    var searchOverlayInputEl = searchOverlayFormEl.querySelector('input');
    var searchOverlayClearButton = searchOverlayFormEl.querySelector('.Search-overlay__clear');
    var searchOverlaySuggestions = searchOverlayFormEl.querySelector('.Search-overlay__curated-suggestions');

    function closeSelf(e) {
      searchOverlayFormEl.classList.remove('active');
      bodyScrollLock.enableBodyScroll(searchOverlayFormEl);

      var fexy_relish_tab = document.getElementById("fexy-relish-tab");
      if (fexy_relish_tab) { fexy_relish_tab.style.display = ""; } 

      dataLayer.push({
        "event": "gaEvent",
        "category": 'search-overlay',
        "action": 'click',
        "label": 'close-overlay',
        "nonInteraction": false
      });
    };

    function clearSearchBox(e) {
      e.preventDefault();
      e.stopPropagation();
      searchOverlayInputEl.value = '';
      const event = new Event('input', {
        bubbles: true,
        cancelable: true,
      });
      const keyEvent = new Event('keyup', {
        bubbles: true,
        cancelable: true,
      });
      searchOverlayInputEl.dispatchEvent(event);
      searchOverlayInputEl.dispatchEvent(keyEvent);
    }

    function stopPropagation(e) {
      e.stopPropagation();
    };

    function handleSearchFormInputChange(e) {
      e.stopPropagation();
      if (searchOverlayInputEl.value.length) {
        searchOverlayClearButton.classList.remove('hidden')
        searchOverlaySuggestions.classList.add('hidden');
      } else {
      //add a small delay so we don't see the suggestion box overlaying this
        setTimeout(() => {
          searchOverlayClearButton.classList.add('hidden')
          searchOverlaySuggestions.classList.remove('hidden');
        }, 200)
      }
    }

    function handleSearchFormSubmit(e) {
      e.preventDefault();
      e.stopPropagation();
      if (searchOverlayInputEl.value.trim()) {
        dataLayer.push({
          "event": "gaEvent",
          "category": "search-overlay",
          "action": "search",
          "label": "manual-submit" + searchOverlayInputEl.value.trim(),
          "nonInteraction": false
        });
        searchOverlayFormEl.submit();
      }
    }
  </script>


<script>

function openSearch(e) {
  var searchForm = document.getElementById('SearchForm');
  searchForm.classList.add('active');

  var fexy_relish_tab = document.getElementById("fexy-relish-tab");
  if (fexy_relish_tab) { fexy_relish_tab.style.display = "none"; } 

  var searchInput = document.getElementById('search-box');
  if (window.innerWidth > 480) {
    searchInput.focus();
  }
  dataLayer.push({
    "event": "gaEvent",
    "category": 'search-overlay',
    "action": 'click',
    "label": 'open-overlay',
    "nonInteraction": false
  });
  bodyScrollLock.disableBodyScroll(searchForm);
}

function handleLeaderboardCloseXClick(e) {
  var leaderBoardElement = document.querySelector('.leaderboard');
  if (leaderBoardElement) {
    leaderBoardElement.style.display = 'none';
  }
}

function handleHeaderHamburgerClick(e) {
  seGlobalState.navIsOpen = !seGlobalState.navIsOpen;
  var navEl = document.querySelector('.Nav');
  var headerEl = document.querySelector('.header-global:not(.header-global--desktop)');

  if (seGlobalState.navIsOpen) {
    navEl.classList.add('Nav--open');
    headerEl.classList.add('header-global--menu-open');

    var fexy_relish_tab = document.getElementById("fexy-relish-tab");
    if (fexy_relish_tab) { fexy_relish_tab.style.display = "none"; } 

  } else {
    navEl.classList.remove('Nav--open');
    headerEl.classList.remove('header-global--menu-open');

    var fexy_relish_tab = document.getElementById("fexy-relish-tab");
    if (fexy_relish_tab) { fexy_relish_tab.style.display = ""; } 

  }
  document.body.style.overflow = seGlobalState.navIsOpen ? 'hidden' : null;
}

function toggleSection(e) {
  var clickedCategory = e.target.closest('.Nav__category');
  var clickedIdx = clickedCategory.getAttribute('data-idx');
  var navEl = clickedCategory.closest('.Nav');
  var categories = navEl.querySelectorAll('.Nav__category');
  categories.forEach(function(category) {
      if (clickedIdx !== category.getAttribute('data-idx')) {
        category.classList.remove('Nav__category--open');
      } else {
        clickedCategory.classList.toggle('Nav__category--open');
      }
  });
};

        var $thisEntry = $(this);
        var winBottom = window.pageYOffset + window.innerHeight,
            entryTop = $thisEntry.offset().top;
        if((winBottom - entryTop) > 0) {
          lastEntry = $thisEntry;
          return false;
        }
      });
      return lastEntry;
    }

    function setEntryInView() {
      scrollIndicator = $('.header-global progress');
      entryInView = lastEntryInView();
      $entryHeader = entryInView.find('.entry-header');
      $entryBody = entryInView.find('.entry-body, .recipe-body');
      if($entryHeader.length && $entryBody.length) {
        entryHeight = $entryHeader.height() + $entryBody.height();
        entryTop = $entryHeader.offset().top;
        scrollIndicator.attr('max', entryHeight);
      } else {
        entryTop = null;
      }
    }
    setEntryInView();

    if(scrollIndicator.length > 0 && typeof seGlobalState === "object" && typeof seGlobalState.currentY !== "undefined") {

      function scrollProgress() {
        if(entryTop !== null) {
          var scrollPercent = Math.round(seGlobalState.currentY + globalNavHeight - entryTop);
          if(scrollPercent >= 0) {
            scrollIndicator.attr('value', scrollPercent);
          } else {
            scrollIndicator.attr('value', entryHeight);
          }
        }
      }
      setInterval(function() {
        if(seGlobalState.didScroll) {
          setEntryInView();
        }
      // One second is probably frequent enough for normal scrolling - if we see a big lag, can decrease
      }, 1000);
      seGlobalState.$window.on("scroll", function() {
        scrollProgress();
        // setScrollVars();
      });
      seGlobalState.$window.on("load resize", function(){
        setEntryInView();
        scrollProgress();
      });

    } // End if page has scroll indicator bar
  } // End if desktop size

});

</script>

          <div class="entry-header-inner">
            <h1 class="title">Essential Indian Street Food: Must-Try Dishes From Around the Country</h1>


                
  





    <div class="author-byline brief">
      <div class="name-contact">
        <span class="author-name">
            <a href="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/user/profile/meher-mirza" class="name">Meher Mirza</a>
        </span>
      </div>
    </div>




            












  <div class="nav-share nav-share-wide">

                <p class="headnote">India offers a vast variety of street foods for the curious traveler to try. Here, in no particular order, are the Indian snacks we think are most worth seeking out.</p>


                







  <div class="pubmod-date">
    <span class="publish-date">Published: <time datetime="2018-08-03">August  3, 2018</time></span>
    <span class="modified-date">Last Updated: <time datetime="2019-08-16">August 16, 2019</time></span>
  </div>



          </div>
        </header>
      
        <div class="entry-body">


          <div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" height="1125" width="1500" alt="Paratha (Indian flatbread) being pulled apart by two hands" class="lazyload" data-src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/06/20180622-paratha-vicky-wasik-39--1500x1125.jpg" data-pin-description="Essential Indian Street Food: Must-Try Dishes From Around the Country" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" rel="noopener" title="Share on Pinterest" data-pin-custom="true" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div><p class="caption">Paratha tears apart into delightfully flaky layers. [Photograph: Vicky Wasik]</p><div class="ad-wrapper body-inline c-inline-ad__wrapper">
        <div class="ad-breakout SE_Rectangle_1-breakout clear-on-refresh"></div>
        <div class="auto-ad" id="entry-body-mobile-0-0" data-ad-unit="SE_Rectangle_1" data-ad-size="[[300,250]]" data-ad-mapping="inline_mapping" data-refresh-time="30000"></div>
      </div>
<p>You may be familiar with ubiquitous snacks like <em><a href="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/05/a-dosa-delicious-how-to-make-the-savory-south-asian-crepes-your-own.html">dosa</a></em> and samosa, but India is home to an extraordinary smorgasbord of street foods, many of which are unfamiliar to even die-hard fans of the country's cuisine. That's because there's a remarkable degree of variation among India's 29 states, each of which features regional and seasonal specialties. </p>
<p>Yet for gastronomy-focused travelers, the destination-worthy street foods of India can be better than any guide. Think sweet hillocks of pearly <em>ponkh</em> (sorghum) from the westernmost state of Gujarat, juxtaposed with savory, spicy <em>sev</em> (fine noodles of fried chickpea dough); <em>sandaal</em>, or steamed cakes made of fermented rice, creamy milk, and almonds, available exclusively during Ramadan; <em>garadu</em>, a winter specialty of the central state of Madhya Pradesh that features deep-fried purple yam soused in <a href="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/2010/06/spice-hunting-asafoetida-hing.html">asafoetida</a>-heavy masala; and <em>chakuli peetha</em>, cakes of steamed rice and lentil that are submerged in spicy red chutney, which you'll find in the eastern state of Odisha.</p>
<p>If I were to paint the peculiarities of my country's foodscape in <em>very</em> broad strokes, I might say that in Goa, Maharashtra, and even Gujaratstates striped along the west coast and influenced by the Portuguese invasionyou will find a predominance of the soft, white, dinner rolllike buns called <em>pao</em> (the word is borrowed from the Portuguese word for "bread," <em>po</em>) and coconut. Meanwhile, in the eastern state of West Bengal, fiery mustard finds its way into many dishesin the form of mustard oil, mustard seeds, or paste, or a sauce that's called <em>kasundi</em>and river fish are a staple of the diet. </p>
<p>In the north, Punjabi dishes marry <em>chole</em> (chickpeas) and potatoes with burnished, flaky wheat-based flatbreads like <em>kulchas</em> and <a href="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/recipes/2018/07/paratha-flaky-south-asian-flatbread.html">parathas</a>. Finally, in the south, kitchens make heavy use of plentiful local crops of bananas, coconut, and rice.</p>
<p>All this bounty means that a truly comprehensive catalog of Indian street food would fill several encyclopedias. This list features a selection of my personal favorites (and therefore leans toward savory and carb-laden items), which, taken collectively, capture a vibrant cross-section of street-food culture from around the country.</p>
<h3>Puris</h3>
<div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" height="1125" width="1500" alt="Pani puri: puri spheres filled with creamy boiled potato, sprouted mung bean, spice- and mint-infused water, and tamarind, date, and jaggery chutney." class="lazyload" data-srcset="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-max-falkowitz-6-pani-puri.jpg 1500w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-max-falkowitz-6-pani-puri-300x225.jpg 300w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-max-falkowitz-6-pani-puri-750x563.jpg 750w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-max-falkowitz-6-pani-puri-625x469.jpg 625w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-max-falkowitz-6-pani-puri-200x150.jpg 200w" data-src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-max-falkowitz-6-pani-puri-1500x1125.jpg" data-pin-description="Essential Indian Street Food: Must-Try Dishes From Around the Country" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" rel="noopener" title="Share on Pinterest" data-pin-custom="true" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div><p class="caption"><em>Pani</em> puri. [Photograph: Max Falkowitz]</p><div class="ad-wrapper body-inline c-inline-ad__wrapper">
        <div class="ad-breakout SE_Rectangle_2-breakout clear-on-refresh"></div>
        <div class="auto-ad" id="entry-body-mobile-0-1" data-ad-unit="SE_Rectangle_2" data-ad-size="[[300,250]]" data-ad-mapping="inline_mapping" data-refresh-time="30000"></div>
      </div>
<p>Puris are small, crisp fried breads made from wheat flour and water. Whether in the form of flat, cracker-like disks or hollow globes with eggshell-thin crusts, they are the foundation of many street snacks across the country (most prominently in Mumbai, Delhi, and Kolkata)often literally, as they frequently function as edible utensils or shells. </p>
<p>They're commonly found in <em><a href="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/recipes/2017/11/papri-chaat-indian-street-snack-recipe.html">papdi chaat</a></em>crunchy puris buried under an avalanche of whisked yogurt, diced potatoes, chickpeas, and pomegranate seeds, then lacquered with tamarind and coriander chutneysand <em>bhel</em> puri, a dish of potatoes, onions, puris, and puffed rice topped with sweet-sour and spicy chutneys and a dusting of sev. (Sometimes the bhel comes with slivers of green mango.) You'll also find them in <em>sev batata</em> puri, a layer of puris served beneath boiled diced potatoes, sev, and date and coriander chutneys, finished with sour green mango and a blanket of whipped yogurt.</p>
<p>For <em>pani</em> puri, the puri spheres come stuffed with creamy boiled potato, sprouted mung bean for added heft and textural contrast, spice- and mint-infused water, and a wash of sweet-sour tamarind, date, and jaggery chutney. </p>
<h3><em>Momos</em></h3>
<div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" height="1125" width="1500" alt="Close-up of momos (round Tibetan dumplings) dressed with chili sauce, on a white dish" class="lazyload" data-src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/images/2015/03/20150304-momo-max-falkowitz-1500x1125.jpg" data-pin-description="Essential Indian Street Food: Must-Try Dishes From Around the Country" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" rel="noopener" title="Share on Pinterest" data-pin-custom="true" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div><p class="caption">[Photograph: Max Falkowitz]</p><div class="ad-wrapper body-inline c-inline-ad__wrapper">
        <div class="ad-breakout SE_Rectangle_3-breakout clear-on-refresh"></div>
        <div class="auto-ad" id="entry-body-mobile-0-2" data-ad-unit="SE_Rectangle_3" data-ad-size="[[300,250]]" data-ad-mapping="inline_mapping" data-refresh-time="30000"></div>
      </div>
<p>In 1959, when the Dalai Lama fled to Dharamsala in India's northern state of Himachal Pradesh, he brought in his wake a wave of loyal Tibetan refugees. With them came the <em>momo</em>, a hulking, hearty steamed dumpling. </p>
<p>Momos took root so firmly that most of India now believes them to be an integral part of the cuisine of our northeastern states (especially in Sikkim, where they displaced the local <em>hyontoen</em> dumpling, made from millet flour and stuffed with cheese). In Tibet, nubs of yak meat are encased in the dumpling shell, but in India, where no yaks are to be found, pork, buffalo, chicken, and vegetables are the fillings of choice. </p>
<p>Tiny momo stalls have sprung up on city streets everywhere in the northeast of India, where a plate of momos is usually served with a fiery chili paste or, sometimes, a cucumber salad. And so warmly has the rest of India embraced them that their hybrid offspring are now infiltrating eateries everywhere. In Delhi, for instance, momos stuffed with paneer and tandoori momosthat is, momos cooked in a tandoor ovenare very popular now.  </p>
<h3>Parathas</h3>
<div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" height="1125" width="1500" alt="Stack of parathas: flaky, layered Indian flatbread." class="lazyload" data-srcset="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180622-paratha-vicky-wasik-1-.jpg 1500w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180622-paratha-vicky-wasik-1--300x225.jpg 300w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180622-paratha-vicky-wasik-1--625x469.jpg 625w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180622-paratha-vicky-wasik-1--200x150.jpg 200w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180622-paratha-vicky-wasik-1--750x563.jpg 750w" data-src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180622-paratha-vicky-wasik-1--1500x1125.jpg" data-pin-description="Essential Indian Street Food: Must-Try Dishes From Around the Country" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" rel="noopener" title="Share on Pinterest" data-pin-custom="true" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div><p class="caption">[Photograph: Vicky Wasik]</p>
<p>Most travelers to old Delhi find themselves in Gali Paranthewali (literally "the lane of parathas"), a tiny alleyway that ribbons through the warren of lanes that is <a href="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chandni_Chowk" class="external" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Chandni Chowk</a>. Here lies treasure: stalls with tiny knolls of spiced, lightly pan-fried green peas, chopped cauliflower, paneer, radish, tomatoes, and potatoes, all waiting to be stuffed into parathas, flat, unleavened wheat breads that, when not stuffed, are usually laminated with ghee or butter, then pan-fried or deep-fried in a wok. </p>
<p>Gali Paranthewali may be Delhi's most famous destination for the flatbread, but it's also purely vegetarian. If you venture further afield in the city, you'll unearth parathas stuffed with a mash of minced chicken or mutton, even egg, and served with accompaniments like pickles, <a href="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/2014/03/panty-essentials-all-about-chutney.html">chutneys</a>, green chilies, and sometimes <em>aloo matar</em> (green peas and potatoes) on the side.</p>
<h3><em>Vadai</em></h3>
<div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" height="1125" width="1500" alt="Vadai: savory fried lentil doughnut served with chutneys" class="lazyload" data-srcset="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-vicky-wasik-1-vadai.jpg 1500w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-vicky-wasik-1-vadai-300x225.jpg 300w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-vicky-wasik-1-vadai-750x563.jpg 750w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-vicky-wasik-1-vadai-625x469.jpg 625w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-vicky-wasik-1-vadai-200x150.jpg 200w" data-src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-vicky-wasik-1-vadai-1500x1125.jpg" data-pin-description="Essential Indian Street Food: Must-Try Dishes From Around the Country" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" rel="noopener" title="Share on Pinterest" data-pin-custom="true" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div><p class="caption">[Photograph: Vicky Wasik]</p><div class="ad-wrapper body-inline c-inline-ad__wrapper">
        <div class="ad-breakout SE_Rectangle_4-breakout clear-on-refresh"></div>
        <div class="auto-ad" id="entry-body-mobile-0-3" data-ad-unit="SE_Rectangle_4" data-ad-size="[[300,250]]" data-ad-mapping="inline_mapping" data-refresh-time="30000"></div>
      </div>
<p>Eaten at breakfast or as a snack, <em>vadai</em> are thick, rugged deep-fried rings made from a batter of ground lentils and fenugreek, sometimes invigorated with the addition of minced onion, ginger, and chilies. The earliest records of vadai date back to AD 1130, in the region now known as Karnataka state. The dish has since taken on a hundred avatars.</p>
<p>There's masala vadai, made with coarsely pured split chickpeas studded with onion and green chilies; <em>keerai</em> vadai, in which the vadai batter is joined by spinach and other greens; <em>aama</em> vadai, made from a variety of dals; and the extremely popular <em>medu</em> vadai, made from <em>urad</em> dal (also called black gram or black lentils). </p>
<p>These crisp, savory fritters can be eaten all on their own, but they're usually served alongside cooling <a href="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/recipes/2018/02/coconut-chutney-recipe.html">coconut chutney</a> and <em>sambhar</em>, a rich stew made from lentils, which you can sink the vadai into, use as a dip, or spoon over the vadai like a sauce, depending on your preference. </p>
<h3><em>Bhutte Ka Kees</em></h3>
<p>Perhaps the best place to try <em>bhutte ka kees</em>, a street snack from the central state of Madhya Pradesh, is in Sarafa Bazaar, a cacophonous night market located in Indore, the state's most populous city, and home to some of its best vendors. The dish is made from grated fresh corn that's sauted in ghee, then simmered in a bath of bubbling-hot milk until it achieves a polenta-like creaminess. It comes garnished with lime juice, coriander, and squiggles of grated coconut.</p>
<h3><em>Jhalmuri</em></h3>
<div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" height="1125" width="1500" alt="Container of jhalmuri, a mixture of puffed rice, cilantro, boiled potato, fried chickpea-flour bits, and onion." class="lazyload" data-srcset="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180731-indian-snacks-jhal-muri-Daniel-Gritzer-5.jpg 1500w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180731-indian-snacks-jhal-muri-Daniel-Gritzer-5-750x563.jpg 750w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180731-indian-snacks-jhal-muri-Daniel-Gritzer-5-300x225.jpg 300w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180731-indian-snacks-jhal-muri-Daniel-Gritzer-5-625x469.jpg 625w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180731-indian-snacks-jhal-muri-Daniel-Gritzer-5-200x150.jpg 200w" data-src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180731-indian-snacks-jhal-muri-Daniel-Gritzer-5-1500x1125.jpg" data-pin-description="Essential Indian Street Food: Must-Try Dishes From Around the Country" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" rel="noopener" title="Share on Pinterest" data-pin-custom="true" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div><p class="caption">[Photograph: Daniel Gritzer]</p>
<p>It's said that <em>jhalmuri</em> owes its popularity to World War II, when street vendors sold <em>muri</em> (puffed rice, an intrinsic part of the Bengali cuisine of east India) to Bengali businessmen and American and British soldiers stationed in Kolkata. This evolved to become jhalmuria sort of crunchy snack mix made up of crisp muri; earthy, spicy masala; crispy bits of fried chickpea flour; flecks of pungent raw onion; boiled potatoes; lemon juice; and chilies, all soused with the lacerating stab of mustard oil and a slick of sour-sweet tamarind water, and eaten straight out of newspaper cones. </p>
<h3><em>Sanpiau</em></h3>
<p>In their cookbook, <em><a href="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.amazon.in/Seven-Sisters-Kitchen-Tales-North/dp/9384030678/?tag=serieats-20" class="external" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Seven Sisters: Kitchen Tales from the North East</a></em>, journalists Purabi Shridhar and Sangita Singh compile homey recipes from people with roots in the seven northeastern states of India, some of which defy Western expectations of what Indian cuisine can be. According to Shridhar and Singh, the typical diet of Mizoram state, for instance, emphasizes the essential taste of a vegetable stripped of any additive, preservative, spice or even the most basic taste-enhancer, salt. </p>
<p>An excellent illustration of that thriftiness with spice is Mizoram's popular rice porridge street snack<em>sanpiau</em>which comes mixed with fermented fish sauce, spring onions, a paste made from cilantro, and a burst of ground black pepper to finish. In the absence of strong dried spices, the predominant flavor is umami from the fish sauce, plus heat from the pepper.</p>
<h3>Kebabs</h3>
<div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" height="1125" width="1500" alt="Seekh Kebab: ground and spiced lamb kebab." class="lazyload" data-srcset="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-vicky-wasik-1-kebab.jpg 1500w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-vicky-wasik-1-kebab-300x225.jpg 300w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-vicky-wasik-1-kebab-625x469.jpg 625w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-vicky-wasik-1-kebab-200x150.jpg 200w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-vicky-wasik-1-kebab-750x563.jpg 750w" data-src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-vicky-wasik-1-kebab-1500x1125.jpg" data-pin-description="Essential Indian Street Food: Must-Try Dishes From Around the Country" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" rel="noopener" title="Share on Pinterest" data-pin-custom="true" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div><p class="caption">[Photograph: Vicky Wasik]</p>
<p>Even before the Mughals muscled their way into the country in the early 16th century, several Muslim sultanates had already taken root in northern India, and these continuous forays into the subcontinent naturally resulted in the mutation of the culinary landscape. In <em><a href="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.amazon.com/Story-Our-Food-K-T-Achaya/dp/817371293X/?tag=serieats-20" class="external" target="_blank" rel="nofollow noopener sponsored">The Story of Our Food</a></em>, Indian food historian K. T. Achaya observes that Muslim culinary influence transformed the spit-roasted meats that were endemic to the region into a wide variety of kebabs, which are now ubiquitous. </p>
<p>At street stalls, you'll find specialties like the Lucknowi <em>galouti</em> kebab: finely ground leg of lamb that's mixed with spices like clove and nutmeg, smoked, then formed into patties and fried. (Their meltingly soft texture was allegedly designed to please a toothless old royal.) There are torpedoes of slightly fatty ground lamb, beef, or chicken <a href="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/recipes/2016/08/seekh-kebab-spiced-grilled-ground-beef-lamb-skewer-recipe.html"><em>seekh</em> kebabs</a>, lightly spiced and impaled on a skewer, eaten with mint and cilantro chutney. Or try satin-soft <em>shammi</em> kebabs, made from lamb pounded with lentils that's boiled, then ground with onions and mint, shaped into patties, and finally pan-fried. </p>
<p>In Hyderabad, you can grab <em>shikampuri</em> kebabs, finely ground parcels of meat stuffed with yogurt and spices. Elsewhere, organ-meat lovers can revel in tender kebabs made from <em>kheeri</em> (udders), <em>kaleji</em> (liver), and other offal.</p>
<p>All told, kebabs come in a staggering variety of styles, more than I can countas chunks of meat, ground meat, or minced meat; whether chicken, mutton, or beef; all precision-engineered through ingenious combinations of fat, spices, marinades, and tenderizers such as yogurt; and eaten off skewers or just off a plate.</p>
<h3><em>Nader Monje</em></h3>
<p>There are many Sufi shrines dotted around the northern Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir, and where there are shrines, there is <em>nader monje</em>. That's because the snack makes use of lotus root, an ingredient that's said to have been blessed by Sufi saints and is intrinsic to the state's cuisine. The mild, crunchy, potato-like root is carved into thin fingers, which are then cloaked in rice flour and plunged into a cauldron of boiling oil, from which they emerge shatteringly crisp and cornflake-crackly. Alongside, there is always chutney to be had, usually made from spicy, tangy onion. </p>
<h3>Frankie</h3>
<div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" height="1125" width="1500" alt="A wrap-style sandwich filled with meat, vegetables, and sauce, with accompanying salad on a plate" class="lazyload" data-src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/03/20180327-pondicheri-chicken-frankie-vicky-wasik-10-1500x1125.jpg" data-pin-description="Essential Indian Street Food: Must-Try Dishes From Around the Country" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" rel="noopener" title="Share on Pinterest" data-pin-custom="true" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div><p class="caption">[Photograph: Vicky Wasik]</p>
<p>In 1967, Amarjit Singh Tibb, a pharmacist from the bustling western coastal metropolis of Mumbai, pledged to create a shawarma for the Indian palate after tasting one on a visit to Beirut. And he did, though it's unclear how his invention ended up with its singular name. </p>
<p>The Tibb's frankie is an egg-washed paratha that's tightly wrapped around craggy pieces of chicken, mutton, paneer, or vegetables, spangled with onions, chilies, chutneys, and the secret Tibb's spice mix that elevates it all. By all appearances, it has much in common with the Kolkata <em>kathi</em> roll, which has recently become popular around the world, but there are differencesthe meat in the kathi roll is encased in a paratha of refined wheat flour, while the frankie usually uses whole wheat, and the Tibb's masala mix is wetter than the masala used for the kathi.</p>
<p>The first Tibb's frankie counter went up at the now-defunct Aga Brothers store in Mumbai's Colaba district and was a resounding success, leading to a welter of independent Tibb's frankie stalls that now crisscross the city. </p>
<h3>Bombay Sandwich</h3>
<div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" height="1125" width="1500" alt="Bombay sandwich: raw vegetables and boiled potato seasoned with chutney and placed between two buttered slices of bread and griddled." class="lazyload" data-srcset="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-max-falkowitz-7-bombay-sandwich.jpg 1500w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-max-falkowitz-7-bombay-sandwich-300x225.jpg 300w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-max-falkowitz-7-bombay-sandwich-750x563.jpg 750w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-max-falkowitz-7-bombay-sandwich-625x469.jpg 625w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-max-falkowitz-7-bombay-sandwich-200x150.jpg 200w" data-src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-max-falkowitz-7-bombay-sandwich-1500x1125.jpg" data-pin-description="Essential Indian Street Food: Must-Try Dishes From Around the Country" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" rel="noopener" title="Share on Pinterest" data-pin-custom="true" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div><p class="caption">[Photograph: Max Falkowitz]</p>
<p>The Bombay sandwich is nothing like its delicate forebear, the English cucumber sandwich. A medley of raw vegetables (tomatoes, onion, cucumber, beet, bell pepper, et cetera), plus boiled potato, spices, and a thick smear of garlic and cilantro chutneys, are placed between two pieces of buttered bread, in whatever combination the customer desires. Pressed into a greased toaster, from which it emerges blistered and bronzed, the sandwich is served cut into bite-size pieces and wiped with more butter and chutney (and sometimes even ketchup). </p>
<h3><em>Dabeli</em></h3>
<div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" height="1125" width="1500" alt="Dabeli: spiced potato mixture with chopped onions, coriander, coconut, peanuts, and pomegranate seeds in a soft white bun." class="lazyload" data-srcset="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180826-indian-snack-dabeli-shutterstock.jpg 1500w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180826-indian-snack-dabeli-shutterstock-750x563.jpg 750w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180826-indian-snack-dabeli-shutterstock-300x225.jpg 300w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180826-indian-snack-dabeli-shutterstock-625x469.jpg 625w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180826-indian-snack-dabeli-shutterstock-200x150.jpg 200w" data-src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180826-indian-snack-dabeli-shutterstock-1500x1125.jpg" data-pin-description="Essential Indian Street Food: Must-Try Dishes From Around the Country" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" rel="noopener" title="Share on Pinterest" data-pin-custom="true" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div><p class="caption">[Photograph: Shutterstock]</p>
<p>The <em>dabeli</em> is the product of a clash of culturesthe potato and the chili first entered western India in the 16th century, thanks to Portuguese invaders, who also brought along a taste for white, yeast-leavened bread. The dabeli, beloved in the western state of Gujarat, is a combination of the three, spiked with a few quintessentially Indian ingredients: A spiced potato mixture gets tossed with chopped onions, coriander, coconut, peanuts, and pomegranate seeds for a touch of sweetness, and everything is heaped into a hunk of pao. The bread is then striped with sweet and spicy chutneys, and a confetti of sev is flung over the top as garnish. </p>
<h3><em>Litti Chokha</em></h3>
<p><em>Litti chokha</em> is rustic, earthy fare that's only recently escaped onto hand carts and street stalls from the home kitchens of the eastern states of Bihar and Jharkhand. <em>Litti</em> are spheres of pastry filled with a paste of dry-roasted gram flour (<em>sattu</em>) and spices such as chili powder, asafoetida, ginger-garlic paste, and <em>amchur</em> (tangy mango powder). The balls are baked until golden, then dipped in ghee. They make a fine vehicle for <em>chokha</em>, a kind of relish made from boiled potato, eggplant, and tomatoes, the latter two of which are charred over an open flame to give their flesh a touch of smoky flavor.</p>
<h3><em>Kothu Parotta</em></h3>
<div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" height="1125" width="1500" alt="Kothu Paratha: shredded paratha cooked with chicken and spices." class="lazyload" data-srcset="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-vicky-wasik-2-kothu-paratha.jpg 1500w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-vicky-wasik-2-kothu-paratha-750x563.jpg 750w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-vicky-wasik-2-kothu-paratha-300x225.jpg 300w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-vicky-wasik-2-kothu-paratha-625x469.jpg 625w, http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819im_/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-vicky-wasik-2-kothu-paratha-200x150.jpg 200w" data-src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/07/20180709-indian-snacks-vicky-wasik-2-kothu-paratha-1500x1125.jpg" data-pin-description="Essential Indian Street Food: Must-Try Dishes From Around the Country" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" rel="noopener" title="Share on Pinterest" data-pin-custom="true" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div><p class="caption">[Photograph: Vicky Wasik]</p>
<p>The Malabari <em>parotta</em>, originating from the Malabar coast of southwest India, is a feathery, crispy-chewy iteration of its northern counterpart, the paratha. It's made of very thin whorls of refined wheat flour dough; when bronzed over a griddle, the whorls flake off at a touch, for a texture and flavor that shares much in common with the Malaysian flatbread <em>roti canai</em>. For a <em>kothu</em> parotta, torn pieces of Malabari parotta are fried up with an assortment of spiced vegetables and meatsanything from beef and mutton to chicken and egg, depending on where in south India you are.</p>
<h3><em>Pyaaz Ki Kachori</em></h3>
<p><em>Pyaaz ki kachori</em> is Rajasthan's iconic street snack, a stuffed, deep-fried flatbread made from a refined-flour dough with a belly full of browned onions, their sweetness tempered with a masala made from coriander, chilies, cumin, and fennel seeds. To wash it down properly, you can go one of two waysa soothing glass of cool <a href="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/02/how-to-make-sweet-or-savory-lassi-the-original-milkshake.html">lassi</a>, or a steaming cup of chai.</p>

<script>
  window.seGlobalMethods = window.seGlobalMethods || {};
  seGlobalMethods.observeIntersection = (element, callback) => {
    const thresholdArray = steps => Array(steps + 1)
     .fill(0)
     .map((_, index) => index / steps || 0)

    const handleIntersect = entries => {
      entries.forEach(entry => {
        callback(entry);
      });
    }

    const observer = new IntersectionObserver(handleIntersect, {
      threshold: thresholdArray(20),
    });
    observer.observe(element);
  }
</script>

  <script>
    $(document).ready(function(){
      var $mobileStickyAd = $('.mobile-sticky-ad');
      $mobileStickyAd.find('button').on('click', function(){
        // Kills the pop-up completely:
        // $mobileStickyAd.remove();
        // Allows for the refresh to bring the unit back into view:
        $mobileStickyAd.addClass('collapsed');
      });
      var googletagCheckInt = 500,
          googletagCheckTO = 10000;
      (function() {
        window.googletag = googletag || {};
        googletag.cmd = googletag.cmd || [];
        googletag.cmd.push(function() {
          googletag.pubads().addEventListener('slotRenderEnded', function(event) {
            try {
              if (_seAds && _seAds.slots && _seAds.slots.length) {
                var mobileStickyAdSlots = _seAds.slots.filter(function(slot){
                      return slot.id === 'mobile-sticky-ad__ad';
                    }).map(function(slot){
                      return slot.googletagSlot;
                    });
                if (mobileStickyAdSlots.length && mobileStickyAdSlots[0] === event.slot) {
                  if(!event.isEmpty) {
                    $mobileStickyAd.removeClass('collapsed');
                  } else {
                    $mobileStickyAd.addClass('collapsed');
                  }
                }
              }
            } catch(e) {
              $mobileStickyAd.addClass('collapsed');
            }
          });
        });
      })();
    });
  </script>

<script>
  $("div.social-links li a").click(function()
  {
    try {
      var event_name = $(this).data("event");
      var location = $(this).data("location");
      dataLayer.push({
        "event": "gaEvent",
        "category": "share", 
        "action": event_name,
        "label": location,
        "nonInteraction": false
      });
    } catch (err) {}
  });

  var _ads_tracker_created = false;

  function create_ads_tracker()
  {
    if (_ads_tracker_created == true)
      return;

    try {
      ga('create', 'UA-962456-13', 'auto', { name: 'ads' } );
      _ads_tracker_created = true;
    } catch(err) {}
  }

  function adsTracking(num, type, campaign, action, dimension, value) {
    if (!_ads_tracker_created)
      create_ads_tracker();

    try {
      ga(num, type, campaign, action, dimension, value);
      ga('ads.send', 'pageview');
    } catch (e) { }
  };
</script>

<script src="http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819js_/https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/@tarekraafat/autocomplete.js@7.2.0/dist/js/autoComplete.min.js"></script>

<script>

  const populatePopularSearches = (popularCategories) => {
    document.querySelector('.Search-overlay__popular')
    .querySelectorAll('a')
    .forEach(( el, idx ) => {
      el.innerText = popularCategories[idx].name
      el.href = popularCategories[idx].url
      el.setAttribute(
        'data-click-id',
        'click-popular-' + popularCategories[idx].name
      )
    })
  }

  try {

  new autoComplete({
    data: {
      src: async () => {
        const topicsUrl = 'http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://www.seriouseats.com/topics?index=categories&term=c%7Crecipes%7Ctopics';
        const categories = await $.ajax({
          url: topicsUrl,
          dataType: 'jsonp',
          jsonp: 'jsonp',
        });

        const flattenedCategories = []

        const walk = (items, depth) => {
          for (const child of items) {
            child.depth = depth
            flattenedCategories.push(child)
            walk(child.children, depth + 1);
          }
        }

        walk(categories.entries[0].children, 0)

        const terms = flattenedCategories.sort((a,b) => parseFloat(b.popularity_score) - parseFloat(a.popularity_score))

        populatePopularSearches(terms.filter(t => t.depth > 0))

        return terms.map(t => t.name)
      },
      cache: true
     },
      placeHolder: "What would you like to cook?",
      selector: "#search-box",
      threshold: 2,
      debounce: 100,
      searchEngine: "strict",
      resultsList: {
        render: true,
          destination: document.getElementById('search-result-box'),
          position: "beforeend",
          element: "ul"
       },
      maxResults: 5,
      highlight: true,
      resultItem: {
        content: (data, source) => {
          source.innerHTML = data.match;
        },
        element: "li"
      },
      onSelection: feedback => {
        feedback.event.stopPropagation();
        feedback.event.preventDefault();
        dataLayer.push({
          "event": "gaEvent",
          "category": 'search-overlay',
          "action": 'search',
          "label": 'autocomplete-selection-' + feedback.selection.value,
          "nonInteraction": false
        });
        window.location = `${window.location.origin}/search?term=${feedback.selection.value}`
      }
    });
  } catch(e) {
    console.error('could not load autocomplete')
  }
</script>

<script>
$(function(){

  function FiniteScroll(linkedEntries, settings) {
    this.defaultSettings = {
      postSelector: ".content-main",
      historyThreshold: 25, // percent above and below the window midpoint; controls when page title and history are updated 
      loadThreshold: 1000 // pixels beyond window bottom; controls when a new post is loaded in
    };
    this.settings = this.setSettings(settings, this.defaultSettings);

    this.postSelector = this.settings.postSelector;
    this.historyThreshold = Math.abs(this.settings.historyThreshold / 100);
    this.loadThreshold = this.settings.loadThreshold;

    // setHistoryThresholdLines sets:
    //   this.roofLine
    //   this.floorLine
    this.setHistoryThresholdLines();

    this.lastEntry = this.getLastEntry();
    this.lastEntryID = this.lastEntry.data("id") || 0;
    this.currentEntryID = this.lastEntryID;
    this.nextUrl = linkedEntries;
    this.counter = 0;
    // this.checkTime = 300;
    this.checkTime = 500;
    this.historyTry = false;
    this.loadTry = false;

    this.init();
  } // FiniteScroll constructor

  FiniteScroll.prototype = {

    init: function() {
      this.setListeners();
    },

    // Determines finite scroll settings based on defaults and user overrides
    setSettings: function(userSettings, defaultSettings) {
      if(!userSettings) { return defaultSettings; }
      var settings = defaultSettings;
      Object.keys(userSettings).forEach(function(key, index) {
        settings[key] = userSettings[key];
      });
      return settings;
    },

    // Determines 'roof' and 'floor' lines to update history and title
    setHistoryThresholdLines: function() {
      var windowHeight = window.innerHeight,
          thresholdPx = this.historyThreshold * windowHeight,
          midLine = windowHeight / 2;
      this.roofLine = Math.round(midLine - thresholdPx);
      this.floorLine = Math.round(midLine + thresholdPx);
    },

    getAllEntries: function() {
      return $( this.postSelector );
    },

    getLastEntry: function() {
      return this.getAllEntries().last();
    },

    /**
     * Set/unset the nopin attribute on pinnable images so Pinterest pinning tool
     * will show only the current post's images
     */
    updateNoPin: function() {
      var obj = this;
      $('img[data-pin-description]').attr("nopin", "nopin");
      $('.content-main[data-id="' + obj.currentEntryID + '"] img[data-pin-description]').removeAttr("nopin");
    },

    /**
     * Update meta tags
     */
    // updateOGMeta: function(title) {
    //   //var ldjson = JSON.parse($("script[type='application/ld+json']").text());
    //   //this.log("updateOGMeta:  ld+json:" + $("script[type='application/ld+json']").text());

    //   var obj = this;
    //   // obj.currentEntryID

    //   var metaImageURL =  $(recipeElem).find('.featured-image img').attr('src');

    //   $('meta[property="og:image"]').attr('content', metaImageURL);
    //   this.log("Updated: og:image url: " + $('meta[property="og:image"]').attr("content"));

    //   var metaDescription =   $(recipeElem).find('.featured-image img').attr('data-pin-description');
    //   $('meta[property="og:description"]').attr('content', metaDescription);
    //   $('meta[name="description"]').attr('content', metaDescription);

    //   var metaUrl =  $(recipeElem).find('link[rel="canonical"]').attr("href");
    //   $('meta[property="og:url"]').attr('content', metaUrl);
    //   $('meta[property="og:title"]').attr('content', title);
    // },

    updateCurrentEntry: function(entryID, title, url) {
      var obj = this;
      obj.currentEntryID = entryID;
      var seTitle = title.indexOf(" | Serious Eats") < 0 ? title + " | Serious Eats" : title;

      try {
        // TODO: Can add a data object in here w/ a popstate listener elsewhere if we want to better control browser navigation
        history.replaceState(null, seTitle, url);
      } catch (err) {}
      document.title = seTitle;

      obj.updateNoPin();
      // obj.updateOGMeta(seTitle);

    }, // updateCurrentEntry

    hasEntryChanged: function() {

      var obj = this,
          allEntries = obj.getAllEntries(),
          winTop = window.pageYOffset,
          winBottom = winTop + window.innerHeight,
          currentRoofLine = obj.roofLine + winTop,
          currentFloorLine = obj.floorLine + winTop;

      allEntries.each(function(i) {
        // TODO: Try to cache some of these
        var thisEntry = $(this),
            betweenEntriesAd = thisEntry.next(".ad-wrapper").find(".auto-ad").filter(':visible').first(), // between-posts ad
            betweenEntriesAdLength = betweenEntriesAd.length, // 0 or 1
            betweenEntriesAdHeight = betweenEntriesAdLength && betweenEntriesAd.outerHeight(true), // 0 or height
            thisEntryID = thisEntry.data("id") || null,
            thisEntryTop = thisEntry.offset().top,
            // post top + post height (including margins if no ad) - margin-top (if no ad) + ad height (including margins)
            thisEntryBottom = Math.round(thisEntryTop + thisEntry.outerHeight(!betweenEntriesAdLength) - (parseInt(thisEntry.css("margin-top")) * (1-betweenEntriesAdLength)) + betweenEntriesAdHeight);

        if(thisEntryID === null || thisEntryTop > winBottom || thisEntryBottom < winTop) {
          // Entry ID is null (should never happen) or entry is off the page; continue loop
          return true;
        }

        // Here, some part of the post is in view
        if(thisEntryBottom > currentFloorLine) {

          // This is current article
          if(thisEntryID != obj.currentEntryID) {
            // Update current post/history
            obj.updateCurrentEntry(thisEntryID, thisEntry.data("title"), thisEntry.data("permalink"));
          }

        } else if(thisEntryBottom < currentRoofLine && i < allEntries.length - 1) {

          // The next entry is the current article; no need to repeat the above logic
          // TODO: The between-entries ad gives a little shift to this... may want to check the top of the next entry against roofLine as well.
          var nextEntry = $(allEntries[i+1]),
              nextEntryID = nextEntry.data("id") || null;

          if(nextEntryID !== null && nextEntryID != obj.currentEntryID) {
            // Update current post/history
            obj.updateCurrentEntry(nextEntryID, nextEntry.data("title"), nextEntry.data("permalink"));
          }

        }

        // Else, the mid-posts break is in the middle of the page, and we don't update the history
        // break loop
        return false;

      });
      
    }, // hasEntryChanged

    loadNextEntry: function() {
      var obj = this,
          winBottom = window.pageYOffset + window.innerHeight,
          lastEntryBottom = obj.lastEntry.offset().top + obj.lastEntry.outerHeight(true);

      if(lastEntryBottom - obj.loadThreshold > winBottom) {

        obj.loadTry = false;
        setTimeout(function(){ obj.fsTOInit(); }, obj.checkTime);

      } else {

        var url = obj.nextUrl.pop();

        if(!url) {return;}

        obj.counter++;

        var requestUrl = "/json/entry?record=" + url + "&counter=" + obj.counter;
        var request = $.ajax({
          url: requestUrl
        }).done(function(data) {

          try {

            try {
              if (!data.hasOwnProperty("body")) {
                return;
              }
              obj.lastEntry.after(data["body"]);
            } catch (err) {}

            try {
              _seAds.targeting.extractTargetingFromPost(data);
            } catch (err) {}

            // The new ad container elements should already be loaded in here.
            typeof _seAds.render === "function" && _seAds.render();

            // TODO: Do we need this?
            // obj.hasEntryChanged();

            // try {
            //   var $lastRecipeEntry = $('.hrecipe').last();
            //   $lastRecipeEntry.find('.recipe-introduction-body p.caption').insertAfter($lastRecipeEntry.find(".recipe-main-photo"));
            // } catch (err) {}

            try {
              self.COMSCORE && COMSCORE.beacon({c1: "2", c2: "14627434"});
            } catch (err) {}

            try {
              dataLayer.push({"event" : "gaPageview"});
              dataLayer.push({
                "event": "gaEvent",
                "category": "finite-scroll",
                "action": "load-next-entry",
                "label": obj.counter,
                "nonInteraction": false
              });
            } catch (err) {}            

            try {
              var $relish_button = $("span#relish-button[data-recipe-id='" + data.post_id + "']");
              if ($relish_button.length > 0)
              {
                if (window.fexyRelish === undefined)
                {
                  $.ajax({
                    url: "http://web.archive.org/web/20210504025819/https://relish.com/scripts/relish.js?key=fad43e07-2ce3-4c04-97a2-ffd099ecbfd9",
                    dataType: "script",
                    cache: true,
                    success: function() {
                      window.fexyRelish.addShopButton($relish_button, null, data.post_id);
                    },
                    async: true
                  });
                }
                else
                {
                  // fexyRelish.addShopButton(BUTTON_SELECTOR, INGREDIENTS_SELECTOR, RECIPE_ID);
                  window.fexyRelish.addShopButton($relish_button, null, data.post_id);
                }
              }
            }
            catch (err) {}

            // Set up new Pinterest buttons
            window.parsePinBtns && window.parsePinBtns();
            seGlobalState.pinImagesLoaded = false;

          } catch (err) {}

          obj.lastEntry = obj.getLastEntry();

          if(obj.nextUrl.length) {
            obj.loadTry = false;
            setTimeout(function(){ obj.fsTOInit(); }, obj.checkTime);
          }
        }); // ajax done
      }
    }, // loadNextEntry

    fsTOInit: function() {
      var obj = this;
      if(obj.loadTry) {
        obj.loadNextEntry();
      } else {
        setTimeout(function(){ obj.fsTOInit(); }, obj.checkTime);
      }
    },

    setListeners: function() {
      var obj = this;
      $(window).on('load resize', function(){
        obj.setHistoryThresholdLines();
      });
      $(window).on('scroll', function() {
        obj.loadTry = true;
        
        if(obj.historyTry) {
          return;
        }

        obj.historyTry = true;
        obj.hasEntryChanged();

        setTimeout(function() {
          obj.historyTry = false;
        }, obj.checkTime - 100);

      });
      obj.fsTOInit();
    } // setListeners

  }; // FiniteScroll prototype

  var linkedEntries = [];
  if(linkedEntries.length < 1) {
    return;
  }

  var pageFS = new FiniteScroll(linkedEntries);

}); // END document.ready
</script>
